channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Torture, Ex-Detainee Is Still Captive of ‘The Darkness’
item.media:description: Suleiman Abdullah Salim endured beatings, sleep deprivation, water dousing and other severe measures.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The United States subjected Suleiman Abdullah Salim to harsh tactics in a secret prison and held him without charge for years. He was found not to be a terrorist threat, but he pays a deep price to this day.
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Pentagon Confronts a New Threat From ISIS: Exploding Drones
item.media:description: Eric Fanning, the secretary of the Army, right, earlier this month in Washington. Mr. Fanning recently assigned a special office he had created to respond to emerging threats and to study how to stop drones.
item.description: The group had been using surveillance drones, but a recent attack that killed two Kurdish fighters highlighted its success in developing an effective new weapon.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia and United States to Host New Diplomatic Meeting on Syria
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated after an airstrike in the rebel-held neighborhood of Douma in the Syrian capital on Wednesday.
item.description: It will be the first high-level diplomacy between the Russians and Americans on Syria since efforts to revive a collapsed cease-fire ended.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Wins a Big Game, but Cheering Is Out of Bounds
item.media:description: Iranian soccer fans held up a flag before a soccer match between Iran and South Korea in Tehran on Tuesday. Clerics urged fans not to cheer for their team during the match, which coincided with one of the most solemn religious holidays in Iran.
item.description: Iran played South Korea in Tehran on Tuesday, the eve of the most solemn religious days in the country. Fans were urged not to cheer out of respect for religious values.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump’s Threat to Jail Clinton Also Targets Democracy’s Institutions
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton on Sunday night in St. Louis during their second debate. Mr. Trump said Mrs. Clinton would “be in jail” if he were president.
item.description: His claim at Sunday’s presidential debate was “a threat to the rule of law,” one political scientist said.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and AMANDA TAUB

item.title: South African Priest Injured in Student Protest
item.description: The Rev. Graham Pugin was injured by a rubber bullet fired by the South African police during student protests in Johannesburg.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: A New Weapon in Russia’s Arsenal, and It’s Inflatable
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The Russian military is using life-size decoy tanks, jets and missile launchers for disguise and deception.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Violence Mounts in Restive Myanmar State, Leaving a Dozen Dead
item.media:description: A soldier patrolling at the entrance of Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, on Monday. Reports indicated a significant escalation of tension in the state, which has long been a site of sectarian conflict.
item.description: A rights group reported the extrajudicial killings of Muslims in Rakhine by the army, days after nine police officers in the border area were killed.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Worries Over King’s Health Shake Thailand
item.media:description: People gathered on Wednesday to pray for King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand outside the hospital in Bangkok where he was being treated.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The country’s prime minister returned abruptly to Bangkok and well-wishers waited at the hospital where the 88-year-old monarch was being treated.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Refugee’s Capture in Germany Is Said to Thwart Terrorist Attack
item.media:description: Police officers at an apartment building in Chemnitz, Germany, on Saturday, where they found more than three pounds of material believed to be TATP, an explosive used in terrorist attacks in France last year.
item.description: The head of the federal domestic intelligence service indicated that the likely target was a Berlin airport and that the suspect had ties to ISIS.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Donald Trump Is ‘Dangerous’ for Global Stability, U.N. Rights Chief Says
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, in Geneva on Wednesday.
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights, doubled down on remarks he gave last month condemning “nationalist demagogues.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Gagra Journal: Bad Pipes, Worse Service: A Soviet Riviera Jewel Is Reborn and Booking Up
item.media:description: A promenade outside the 240-room Amra International in Gagra, Georgia. After a long slump, the colonnaded property is enjoying something of a renaissance.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: After a long slump that began with the collapse of the Soviet Union, a once exclusive sanitarium along Georgia’s Black Sea coast is enjoying something of a renaissance.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Lawyers for Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Resign
item.description: Mr. Abdeslam, the sole surviving assailant from the Nov. 13 terrorist assaults, has remained silent and has indicated that he no longer wants representation.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Sinosphere: At Hong Kong Swearing-In, Some Lawmakers Pepper Their Oath With Jabs
item.media:description: Leung Kwok-hung ripped up a copy of the Chinese government’s restrictive ruling on Hong Kong election procedures after taking the oath of office in the Legislative Council on Wednesday. The yellow umbrella is a symbol of the 2014 pro-democracy protests.
item.description: The acts of defiance, directed at Beijing as some called for outright independence for the semiautonomous territory, seemed to augur a stormy legislative term.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong

item.title: Emerging Climate Accord Could Push A/C Out of Sweltering India’s Reach
item.media:description: Air-conditioning units in New Delhi.
item.description: A phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons could have a major effect on climate change but would make air-conditioning more expensive just as many Indians are becoming able to afford it.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Philippines’ Leader, Rodrigo Duterte, Wants to Ban Public Smoking
item.media:description: A man with an electronic cigarette in Manila on Tuesday.
item.description: Mr. Duterte, who has been targeting dealers and users in an aggressive campaign against illegal drugs, is now turning his attention to tobacco.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In India, a Day to Burn Demons Singes Pakistan, Too
item.media:description: Indians added fireworks to an effigy bearing the image of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan in the likeness of Ravana the Hindu demon king on Monday.
item.description: The Hindu festival of Dussehra re-enacts the slaying of a 10-headed demon. But in a season of tensions, this year’s festival has taken on a Pakistani-themed motif.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: ‘Clown Hysteria’ Spreads to Britain
item.description: A mix of childish pranks and more serious menacing appears to have migrated from the United States, leading to anti-clown patrols in parts of Britain.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Newspaper Closes in Hungary, and Hungarians See Government’s Hand
item.media:description: Staff members from the Hungarian newspaper Nepszabadsag outside the company’s offices in Budapest on Sunday. They were denied access.
item.description: Nepszabadsag, Hungary’s largest opposition paper, has halted publication after years of financial losses. Some also say political interference played a role.
item.dc:creator: HELENE BIENVENU

item.title: Gunmen Attack Crowded Shiite Shrine in Kabul
item.description: The attack came on the eve of Ashura, one of the most solemn holidays on the Shiite calendar.
item.dc:creator: ZAHRA NADER and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar in Chinese Prison, Is Given Human Rights Award
item.media:description: Ilham Tohti, a Uighur scholar sentenced to life imprisonment on charges of of separatism, in 2010.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Tohti, who was jailed after speaking out against repression in his native Xinjiang, has been depicted by Beijing as promoting separatism.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere: For China’s Leaders, U.S. Election Scandals Make the Case for One-Party Rule
item.media:description: Students watching an online broadcast of the first United States presidential debate at a cafe in Beijing last month.
item.description: Even before the most recent scandal involving Donald J. Trump, the Chinese news media has depicted him and Hillary Clinton as puppets of wealthy elites.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Reporter Who Wrote of Military-Civilian Clash Says He Can’t Leave Pakistan
item.description: The journalist said he had been placed on an “exit control list” days after reporting a confrontation over the military’s handling of Islamist groups.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Vietnam Arrests Mother Mushroom, a Top Blogger, for Criticizing Government
item.media:description: The Vietnamese blogger Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh in 2015.
item.description: Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, a co-founder of the Network of Vietnamese Bloggers, has challenged leaders over topics including a dump of toxic chemicals.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘We Sleep Afraid, We Wake Up Afraid’: A Child’s Life in Yemen
item.media:description: My son, Yousef, 2.
item.description: The bombs shake the house at night and blow open doors and windows. How can a father explain war to his children?
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED al-ASAADI

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Tough Talk but Little Action From Lieberman as Israel’s Defense Minister
item.media:description: Israeli police officers carried the coffin of Yosef Kirma, a fellow officer, during his funeral on Sunday in Jerusalem. He was killed that day in an attack by a Palestinian gunman.
item.description: Having criticized the government five months ago for its handling of security, the hard-liner Avigdor Lieberman has not done much to reshape Israeli policies.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere: Henan Province, a Butt of Jokes in China, Gets a Champion in Court
item.media:description: Tourists crowding ancient Buddhist sculptures at the Longmen Grottoes in Luoyang, in the central Chinese province of Henan, during the recent National Day holiday. Henan is celebrated as a birthplace of Chinese civilization but disparaged by some for a less glorious present.
item.description: After an aspiring TV celebrity ridiculed the province, a science journalist from the region resolved to sue for damages to his reputation as a resident there.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Building Collapse in Chinese City of Wenzhou Kills at Least 22
item.description: The toll makes it one of the deadliest episodes of its kind in recent years. Six people have been pulled from the rubble, including a 3-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: What in the World: Who’s That Voice Asking for Scrap Metal in Mexico? A 10-Year-Old Girl
item.description: A collector of recyclable goods got tired of shouting through a megaphone, so he asked his daughter to record a message for him. It’s now used by hundreds of merchants.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: When You Have to Go, Japanese Rest Stops Won’t Keep You Waiting
item.media:description: Monitors at the rest stop let visitors see immediately which stalls inside the restroom are empty.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Amenities like five times as many stalls for women, and monitors showing the vacant ones, aim to make sure traffic is the only delay to worry about.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Russia-U.S. Partnership, Driven to a New Low
item.description: The next American president will have to recognize that Russia is less interested in a détente than in being a victor with no need to justify itself.
item.dc:creator: MAXIM TRUDOLYUBOV

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How the U.N. Can Save Aleppo
item.media:description: Syrians walked through the rubble of Aleppo on Wednesday, after air strikes in the northern part of the city.
item.description: The world must not stand by while the Assad regime massacres Syrian civilians. Here is a plan.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED BIN ABDULRAHMAN AL-THANI
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: India’s Eternal Inequality
item.description: Even in a modernizing nation, caste remains a fault line running through every facet of society.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
